source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: Zircaloy forms a dense barrier oxide layer which becomes porous after some critical time, allowing water to penetrate. When this porous layer is formed, corrosion is controlled by a thin dense interlayer at the metal/oxide interface.

source_id: STP1132-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_9th Volume_027_chunk5
evidence_span: The impedance measurements of a variety of thick oxide layer samples showed that the corrosion rate and the effective thickness of the dense interlayer are correlated.

evidence_span: The impedance measurements of a variety of thick oxide layer samples showed that the corrosion rate and the effective thickness of the dense interlayer are correlated.

evidence_span: This oxide crystallizes to fine equiaxed tetragonal grains, which grow and transform at a certain critical size to monoclinic grains.

evidence_span: which grow and transform at a certain critical size to monoclinic grains.

evidence_span: However, even within this dense interlayer with a columnar structure, a certain fraction of the oxide has a tetragonal structure.
